tit.e: Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido (the Nara Highway passing over Tatsuta)
Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido (the Nara Highway passing over Tatsuta)
Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido (the Nara Highway passing over Tatsuta)

sen.j: 竜田越奈良街道（たつたごえならかいどう）は、奈良に至る「奈良街道」の一つ。
sen.e: The Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido is one of the highways to Nara.
The Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido is one of the highways to Nara.
The Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido is one of the highways to Nara.

sen.j: 大阪と奈良を結ぶ街道の一つであり、斑鳩町の竜田（龍田神社付近）を通る「竜田道」の一つである。
sen.e: It is one of the highways connecting Osaka and Nara and is one of the 'Tatsuta-michi's' (Tastsuta road) which run through Tatsuta of Ikaruga-cho (near Tatsuta-jinja shrine).
It is one of the highways connecting Osaka and Nara and is one of the "Tatsuta-michi's" (Tastsuta road) which run through Tatsuta of Ikaruga-cho (near Tatsuta-jinja shrine).
It is one of the highways connecting Osaka and Nara and is one of the 'Tatsuta-michi's' (Tastsuta road) which run through Tatsuta of Ikaruga-cho (near Tatsuta-jinja shrine).

sen.j: 現在は国道25号が踏襲している。
sen.e: At present, National Route 25 follows its path.
At present, National Route 25 follows its path.
At present, National Route 25 follows its path.

sen.j: 龍田（三郷町の龍田大社付近）を越えることから「竜田越」とよばれるようになった。
sen.e: As the highway crosses over Tatsuta (near Tatsuta-taisha shrine of Sango-cho), it came to be called 'Tatsuta-goe' (竜田越: 越える or koeru means to cross over something).
As the highway crosses over Tatsuta (near Tatsuta-taisha shrine of Sango-cho), it has come to be called 'Tatsuta-goe' (竜田越: 越える or koeru means to cross over something).
sen.cmt: it came to be → it has come to be
sen.e: As the highway crosses over Tatsuta (near Tatsuta-taisha shrine of Sango-cho), it has come to be called 'Tatsuta-goe' (竜田越: 越える or koeru means to cross over something).

sen.j: また、大阪府内では「渋川道」ともいわれる。
sen.e: Also its portion within Osaka Prefecture is called 'Shibukawa-michi' (Shibukawa road).
Also its portion within Osaka Prefecture is called 'Shibukawa-michi' (Shibukawa road).
Also its portion within Osaka Prefecture is called 'Shibukawa-michi' (Shibukawa road).

sen.j: 概要・歴史
sen.e: Outline and history
Outline and history
Outline and history

sen.j: 飛鳥時代に、難波津・四天王寺と斑鳩町・法隆寺を結ぶ街道として整備された。
sen.e: It was developed in the Asuka period as a highway connecting Shitenno-ji temple of Naniwazu and Horyu-ji temple of Ikaruga-cho.
It was developed in the Asuka period as a highway connecting Shitenno-ji temple of Naniwazu and Horyu-ji temple of Ikaruga-cho.
It was developed in the Asuka period as a highway connecting Shitenno-ji temple of Naniwazu and Horyu-ji temple of Ikaruga-cho.

sen.j: 沿道にある大聖勝軍寺を含め、いずれも聖徳太子にゆかりのある地域と関わりがある。
sen.e: This highway runs through a number of areas and sites noted in connection with Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku) such as Daisei Shogun-ji Temple which stands at its roadside.
This highway runs through a number of areas and sites noted in connection with Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku) such as Daisei Shogun-ji Temple which stands at its roadside.
This highway runs through a number of areas and sites noted in connection with Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku) such as Daisei Shogun-ji Temple which stands at its roadside.

sen.j: 聖徳太子自身もこの街道を往復していたといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Prince Shotoku himself travelled up and down this highway.
It is said that Prince Shotoku himself travelled up and down this highway.
It is said that Prince Shotoku himself travelled up and down this highway.

sen.j: 奈良時代になると、難波京と平城京を結ぶ街道として利用された。
sen.e: In the Nara period, this highway was used as one connecting between Naniwa-kyo (the Naniwa Palace) and Heijo-kyo (the Heijo Palace).
In the Nara period, this highway was used as one connecting Naniwa-kyo (the Naniwa Palace) and Heijo-kyo (the Heijo Palace).
In the Nara period, this highway was used as one connecting Naniwa-kyo (the Naniwa Palace) and Heijo-kyo (the Heijo Palace).

sen.j: 最短ルートである暗越奈良街道が急峻な山越えであるため、比較的坂の緩い平坦路として重宝された。
sen.e: As Kurayami-goe Nara Kaido, the shortest route between the two places, had to pass a steep mountain path, Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido was found useful as a flat route having relatively gentle ups and downs.
As Kurayami-goe Nara Kaido, the shortest route between the two places, had a steep mountain path, Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido was found useful as a flat route having relatively gentle ups and downs.
sen.cmt: had to pass a steep mountain path → had a steep mountain path
sen.e: As Kurayami-goe Nara Kaido, the shortest route between the two places, had a steep mountain path, Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido was found useful as a flat route having relatively gentle ups and downs.

sen.j: 斑鳩より東は「横大路 (奈良県)」（北の横大路）といわれた。
sen.e: The eastern section of the highway from Ikaruga was called 'Yoko-oji' (横大路) (Nara Prefecture) (also called Kita no Yoko-oji).
The eastern section of the highway from Ikaruga was called 'Yoko-oji' (横大路) (Nara Prefecture) (also called Kita no Yoko-oji).
The eastern section of the highway from Ikaruga was called 'Yoko-oji' (横大路) (Nara Prefecture) (also called Kita no Yoko-oji).

sen.j: また、現在の大和郡山市横田付近で「中街道 (下ツ道)」に合流した。
sen.e: And it joined 'Naka Kaido' (its old name being Shimotsu-michi) at around today's Yokota of Yamato Koriyama City.
And it joined 'Naka Kaido' (its old name being Shimotsu-michi) at around today's Yokota of Yamato Koriyama City.
And it joined 'Naka Kaido' (its old name being Shimotsu-michi) at around today's Yokota of Yamato Koriyama City.

sen.j: かつて、大和川付け替え前は、途中の「河内国府」（現在の藤井寺市国府）で「長尾街道」「東高野街道」と離合した。
sen.e: Prior to the rerouting of the River Yamato, Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido once met with and parted from other highways such as 'Nagao Kaido' and 'Higashi Koya Kaido' at a place along its route where 'Kawachi Kokufu' (Kawachi Province's office) stood (today's Kou, Fujiidera City).
sen.cmt: 「河内国府」は地名であるようなニュアンスの文章ですが、これが地名であったという表記は（私が調べた限りでは）見当たりませんでした。河内国府が存在したことから国府（こう）という地名が残ったと考えられるので、河内国府そのものが最初から地名であったわけではないと判断しています。
sen.e: Prior to the rerouting of the River Yamato, Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido once met with and parted from other highways such as 'Nagao Kaido' and 'Higashi Koya Kaido' at a place along its route where 'Kawachi Kokufu' (Kawachi Province's office) stood (today's Kou, Fujiidera City).

Prior to the rerouting of the River Yamato, Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido once met with and parted from other highways such as 'Nagao Kaido' and 'Higashi Koya Kaido' at a place along its route where 'Kawachi Kokufu' (Kawachi Province's office) stood (today's Kou, Fujiidera City).

sen.j: また、付近で石川 (大阪府)を越えて国分村を経由し、さらに夏目茶屋付近を渡し船で越えていた。
sen.e: It crossed a creek called Ishikawa (Osaka Prefecture) and passed through Kokubu-mura village and then connected to a ferry across the River Yamato near a place named Natsume-jaya.
It crossed a creek called Ishikawa (Osaka Prefecture) and passed through Kokubu-mura village and then connected to a ferry across the River Yamato near a place named Natsume-jaya.
It crossed a creek called Ishikawa (Osaka Prefecture) and passed through Kokubu-mura village and then connected to a ferry across the River Yamato near a place named Natsume-jaya.

sen.j: 大和川付け替え後は必然的に河内国府を通らない大和川を越えないルートとなった。
sen.e: After the River Yamato was rerouted, it inevitably became a course which would neither pass through Kawachi Kokufu area nor cross the River Yamato.
After the River Yamato was rerouted, it inevitably became a course which would neither pass through Kawachi Kokufu area nor cross the River Yamato.
After the River Yamato was rerouted, it inevitably became a course which would neither pass through Kawachi Kokufu area nor cross the River Yamato.

sen.j: 明治時代に入ると、国分村の北に国豊橋が架けられ、亀ノ瀬の対岸の大和川南岸壁を開削して新たなルートが開設された。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, its new route was developed by building Kunitoyo-bashi Bridge at the north of Kokubu-mura village and laying a road on the south bank of the River Yamato.
In the Meiji period, its new route was developed by building Kunitoyo-bashi Bridge at the north of Kokubu-mura village and laying a road on the south bank of the River Yamato.
In the Meiji period, its new route was developed by building Kunitoyo-bashi Bridge at the north of Kokubu-mura village and laying a road on the south bank of the River Yamato.

sen.j: 比較的平坦だったため現在に至るまでメインルートとなっており、現在は国道25号に指定されている。
sen.e: As this highway was relatively flat, it has been used as a major traffic route till today, which is currently designated as National Route 25.
As this highway was relatively flat, it has been used as a major traffic route till today, which is currently designated as National Route 25.
As this highway was relatively flat, it has been used as a major traffic route till today, which is currently designated as National Route 25.

sen.j: なお、柏原から三郷にかけては、北側の山道越え（信貴山越と一部重なる）、大和川の北岸に沿うルート（いわゆる亀の瀬越）、対岸の南側を沿うルート（現在の国道25号）など、複数のルートがある。
sen.e: In addition, there are more than one route between Kashiwara and Sango; the northern mountain path (partly duplicating with Mount Shigi-goe route), the route along the north bank of the River Yamato (so-called Kamenose-goe) and the route along the south bank of the River Yamato (today's National Route 25).

In addition, there are more than one route between Kashiwara and Sango; the northern mountain path (partly duplicating with Mount Shigi-goe route), the route along the north bank of the River Yamato (so-called Kamenose-goe) and the route along the south bank of the River Yamato (today's National Route 25).

In addition, there are more than one route between Kashiwara and Sango; the northern mountain path (partly duplicating with Mount Shigi-goe route), the route along the north bank of the River Yamato (so-called Kamenose-goe) and the route along the south bank of the River Yamato (today's National Route 25).

sen.j: 柏原市内で、「亀の瀬」とよばれる地域を通るが、本街道としては現在に至るまで、難所として知られた。
sen.e: The highway passes through a place called 'Kamenose' in Kashiwara City, which has been known till today as a rough spot.
The highway passes through a place called 'Kamenose' in Kashiwara City, which has been known till today as a rough spot.
The highway passes through a place called 'Kamenose' in Kashiwara City, which has been known till today as a rough spot.

sen.j: 明治時代以降に鉄道が敷設されたときに亀ノ瀬トンネルが掘られたが、軟弱地盤のため、崩壊して放棄された。
sen.e: When a railroad was constructed after the Meiji period, Kamenose tunnel was built, but the tunnel caved in due to the soft ground, and the railroad had to be abandoned.
When a railroad was constructed after the Meiji period, Kamenose tunnel was built, but the tunnel caved in due to the soft ground, and the railroad had to be abandoned.
When a railroad was constructed after the Meiji period, Kamenose tunnel was built, but the tunnel caved in due to the soft ground, and the railroad had to be abandoned.
